 BACKGROUND AND RECENT DEVELOPMENTS The Conflict and its Consequences 1. Afghanistan is one of the poorest and longest-suffering countries arnong the members of the World Bank. An estimated seven million people remain vulnerable to hunger and very large numbers are dependent on a massive inflow of food aid. Afghanistan's infrastructure has been destroyed or degraded; its human resource base severely depleted; and its social capital eroded. State institutions are largely non-functional, and the economy and society have become increasingly fragmented. 2. The Afghanistan Interim Administration (AIA) has moved quickly to restore basic government functions and re-establish international relations. However, expectations among the population for a "peace dividend" are high, and if the AIA and its successor do not deliver results relatively quickly, the prospects for further progress and the peace process will dim. 3. Despite being hampered by very limited capacity and the difficult security situation in many parts of the country, the AIA has made considerable progress and has gained widespread international recognition. The AIA presented a draft National Development Framework to the Interim Donors Group on April 2, 2002, which laid out the AIA's development strategy. Features of the Existing Education System 4. By any statistical measure, the situation facing the education system in Afghanistan is dire. The most informed estimates (UNESCO EFA 2000 report) indicate that Afghanistan's education indicators are among the worst in the world, with girls and rural populations particularly disadvantaged. The gross enrollment rate is estimated at 43 percent for boys and only 3 percent for girls; 80 percent of school buildings at all levels, most teacher training colleges, and vocational-technical facilities have been damaged or destroyed. A large number of qualified teachers have fled the country, taken jobs outside of education, work in refugee camps, or have been killed. The curriculum has not been revised for 30 years, and virtually no modem educational practices have been introduced for decades. Most teachers and administrators have not been paid for over eight months, and salary levels are set well below a living wage. In summary, the education system has very limited capacity to supply basic inputs, i.e., buildings, teachers, materials, and textbooks. 5. Participation in secondary education is extremely low, seriously limiting the capacity of the system to produce skilled professionals and informed leadership. While reliable enrollment data for secondary education levels do not exist yet, estimates for 2001 range from 220,000 to 300,000, or roughly 5-11% of the school age population. No recent information is available on the number of students per secondary grade, nor on survival rates through grade 12. In 1993, roughly 3 students per 100 enrolled in grade 1 completed the 12th grade. At the end of 2001, the number of girls enrolled in secondary grades countrywide was close to nil: the Taliban authorities had closed all of the limited available girls' schools. 6. The attendance rate in tertiary education is among the lowest in the world over a period of at least 30 years. In 1995, only 2% of the population over 25 years of age had any tertiary I
 education, while the average is 5.7% worldwide. Higher education in Afghanistan is mainly provided by five universities, fourteen teacher training colleges and a small number of polytechnics and institutes. There is a near total lack of equipment, teaching and learning materials and furniture in most institutions. The institutional capacity in tertiary education has been depleted by brain drain, and a permanent lack of resources has prevented those professionals remaining in the country to participate in national and international academic networks and pedagogical developments related to teaching and learning. 7. Pre-service teacher training is largely defunct, while some in-service teacher training has been provided, primarily by NGOs and other agencies. A large number of qualified teachers have fled the country, taken jobs outside of education, work in refugee camps, or have been killed. 8. While females' participation rates in secondary education and tertiary education have been historically lower than boys', the gender gap has reached unprecedented heights since 1995. Of an estimated 21,000 teachers who staff government and NGO-run primary education schools, only 12% are females. Most female teachers work outside of government schools in schools supported by NGOs and home-based schools. Only about half of all primary education teachers have completed grade 12, the official minimum qualification. 9. Management of the system is highly centralized, with few qualified educators, managers, administrators, planners or technicians. There is a complete absence of any information- communication technology, with no computers in the two main education ministries. Institutional capacity in the ministries is extremely weak, with limited experience in planning, setting of priorities, and system management. Issues of language and curriculum content will need to be addressed once mechanisms for policy development have been set in place, ensuring broad-based consultation with civil society. 10. An estimated 400,000 children, one-third of the total Afghan children in primary school, attend NGO-run schools and an estimated 170,000 refugee children are enrolled in UN- supported camps in Pakistan. An unknown number attend regular schools in Iran, madrassas, home schools, and other alternative venues. It is difficult to predict how many refugees and Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) will return, and whether they will return to their place of origin. Returning families whose children have started education will want them to continue, and many other families will want a fresh opportunity for their children. 11. The lack of opportunities for education and the disruption caused by war, migration, and economic hardship have created entire generations with limited or disrupted education. There is an urgent need for technical and vocational education to provide skills for national reconstruction, and to assist the insertion of youth, women, ex-combatants and others into the labor force. There are approximately 300,000 war widows in Kabul alone, most of whom lack basic skills for sustaining livelihood. The number of children, youth, and young adults whose education was disrupted is estimated at nine million. Some of them need to complete their primary schooling, while others need to complete secondary school or university to be eligible for many occupations. All of these groups require educational services that are tailored to their particular needs. 12. In order to achieve an 85 percent Net Enrollment Rate (NER) within 10 years, using a very conservative estimate of a constant school age population of 4.5 million children, an 2
 additional 43,500 teachers and 13,851 schools are required. The recurrent costs implied in such an expansion are large by any measure. The budgetary impact will be even greater if teacher salaries are increased to a living wage. In short, new approaches to education must be found - both for the immediate needs and for the future. 13. While the challenges the education system faces are enormous, there is a prevailing atmosphere of excitement, expectation, and determination in schools and communities throughout the country. Despite an almost total lack of resources and teacher salary arrears of more than six months, thousands of Afghan teachers and students are registering for classes, congregating in schools weeks before they open, helping with repairs and feeding on the excitement of being able to have schools again. Parents are keen to return the children to school. The most common estimate of school age children is 4.5 million. The girls' schools that opened for informal winter sessions in all parts of the country after the defeat of the Taliban are overflowing. At the University of Kabul, over 18,000 students took the admissions exam. This commitment to education at all levels will be an important force in rebuilding the system. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY: FROM EMERGENCY TO DEVELOPMENT 14. The emergency education program encompasses all priority areas that require immediate attention to get the education system up and running. This includes rehabilitation of schools, textbooks, teacher training, capacity building, and recurrent costs (salaries and operating costs). The program also supports the efforts needed to initiate policy and structural reforms, thus guaranteeing the sector's sustainability in the recovering economy of Afghanistan. 15. A two-year recovery program for the Education Sector in Afghanistan, estimated at US$225 million, has been submitted for consideration to the international donor community. The program is based on the Comprehensive Needs Assessment (CNA) carried out in February/March 2002 by the AIA and a number of donors, including IDA. There is an estimated US$130 million in available financing under the emergency program, leaving a financing gap of approximately US$95 million, or 45% of total requirements over the next two years. Among sub- sectors, the tertiary sub-sector is relatively under-subscribed for donor support, whereas the primary sub-sector is relatively better off, particularly for physical rehabilitation of schools and to support girls' enrollment and participation.  IDA ASSISTANCE STRATEGY Afghanistan's Relations with IDA 17. Afghanistan is a member of IDA, IFC, IMF, and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Afghanistan became a member of the IMF and World Bank in 1955. IDA has provided 21 development credits to Afghanistan since 1964 in a wide range of sectors including education, roads and agricultural activities. Of the original US$230 million approved by IDA for Afghanistan, US$83 million was disbursed and US$147 million was subsequently canceled. IDA operations were suspended shortly after the 1979 Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, and the Resident Mission in Kabul was closed. Afghanistan has repaid US$9.2 million to IDA and was up-to-date on debt service payments until June 1992, when the country went into non-accrual status. Lending operations remained suspended due to the continuing fighting, absence of a national govermment, and Afghanistan's entry into non-accrual status with IDA. 18. Afghanistan's Arrears to International Financial Institutions (IFI. Resuming normal financial relations with the IFIs will require Afghanistan to clear outstanding arrears which total, as of January 31, 2002, around US$51 million including US$25.2 million to IDA, about US$16 million to the ADB, and US$9.8 million to the IMF. The AIA is committed to clearing its arrears to IDA by the end of the summer 2002, which will set the stage for a resumption of regular lending from the IFIs. 19. IDA has not extended any credits to Afghanistan since 1979, although it has remained engaged with the assistance community. Efforts have included continuous monitoring of political and economic developments; managing selective investments in the Afghan refugee communities; working closely with the UN and donors; undertaking knowledge-building and knowledge-sharing activities; and providing analytical and strategic depth for the work of the wider assistance community.! The Transitional Support Strategy 20. IDA's Transitional Support Strategy (TSS), which was presented to the Board with the Emergency Public Administration Project, is predicated on the need for well-coordinated efforts by Afghanistan's development partners to realize Afghanistan's reconstruction and development priorities. The key objectives of IDA's assistance over the next six to nine months are to assist the authorities in establishing capacity in areas essential to facilitate the reconstruction program; and to support high-priority reconstruction activities that can also help jump-start economic activity. In the near term, IDA's engagement with the AIA is likely to be mainly at the central level, until such time when there is effective decision-making at the sub-national level, and the countrywide security situation improves. Consequently, to deliver assistance outside of Kabul, it will be vital to utilize the experiences and networks of NGOs and UN agencies, and to develop mechanisms to channel funds directly to community groups or traditional governance structures. 21. Assistance to Afghanistan, for both recurrent and capital expenditures, is likely to be received from various donors and delivered through a variety of mechanisms. One mechanism to assist in such coordinated funding is the multi- donor, IDA-administered Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust Fund (ARTF) that will provide financing for priority expenditures including recurrent costs. Donor funding for recurrent expenditures, including wage payments, is an essential element of the support needed since the scope for own-revenue collection is now very limited. Rationale for IDA Involvement in the Education Sector 22. The AIA, IDA and other donors are developing a Comprehensive Development Framework (CDF) to meet the needs of the education sector. Under this approach, and as a first step to a CDF, a programmatic approach for identifying funding requirements has been prepared. Specifically, in order to delineate short-, medium- and long-term investment requirements and plans, a series of joint donor needs assessments have been undertaken, resulting in a consolidated analysis of investment requirements and indicative funding for key activities across sub-sectors (primary, secondary, tertiary, non-formal, technical/skills development). 23. In light of the very serious situation facing the education sector, there has been a concerted effort by donors participating in the needs assessment to ensure that inputs are appropriately sequenced, balancing both the urgency of providing some specific inputs for allowing education service delivery to get underway, and laying the foundation, at an early stage, for the medium- and longer-term need for sound policy and planning processes to be set in place. This approach attempts to maximize complementarity of inputs and the comparative advantages of each assisting agency. However, based on this approach, it appears that the primary and secondary sectors are relatively over-subscribed by donors, whereas tertiary education and vocational and skills development are under-subscribed (see Appendix III). 24. The investment strategy recommended by the joint donor Comprehensive Needs Assessment reflects an overall strategy of: (i) supporting rapid expansion of education services where demand is greatest through the flexible and efficient use of multiple delivery systems (government, NGO, private sector), while (ii) building the capacity of sector institutions to plan for and implement reconstruction of the system. In this respect, ADB, the Islamic Development Bank (IDB) and a number of bilateral donors are funding rehabilitation and construction of primary and secondary schools, and related institution capacity-building. UNICEF and USAID are funding the Back-to-School Program, which provides training, materials, and other quality inputs to primary and secondary schools. For IDA, it was agreed that support to policy formulation, capacity building, ECD, NFE, technical and vocational training, tertiary education, and internet communications and distance learning facilities are priorities. 25. IDA's extensive global experience in supporting these types of interventions in development, post-conflict and emergency situations provides a comparative advantage for its assistance. IDA's priority is to ensure that sector development takes place through the establishment of a sound policy framework through a process of extensive civil society consultation and, especially, the full participation of women. This is particularly important at the tertiary level where it is essential to rebuild a cadre of professionals and leaders to meet the needs of a modem Afghanistan. Additionally, it is essential to ensure that after more than two decades of relative isolation, decision-makers in Afghanistan have the benefit of IDA's 6
 understanding of global good practices for supporting equity, quality, access and accountability in education system building and reform. 26. The Afghanistan education strategy has been developed following careful analysis and assessment of lessons learned through IDA's involvement in both Bosnia and East Timor, and elsewhere, over recent years. It also draws upon the extensive knowledge and experience of other development partners in specific areas -- such as UNICEF in the field of ECD and international NGOs in the field NFE -- where IDA can provide immediate support that might otherwise not be available. There has been an intensive process of consultation within IDA to maximize consistency in approach with other sectoral inputs, particularly for Community Driven Development (CDD) and the coordination of support at local and community levels. THE PROPOSED PROJECT Project Objectives and Components 27. The overall objective of the Project is to selectively support the Government of Afghanistan's emergency education program. Specifically, the Project will help: (a) increase access to education opportunities in the formal and non-fornal systems for under-served groups, especially women and girls; (b) reform education management at all levels, in partnership with civil society, NGOs and the private sector; and (c) introduce modern information technologies for communications and distance learning. 28. To achieve the above project objectives, the Project will include the following components: 29. Component 1: Promoting Skills Development and Learning (estimated cost US$5.8 million equivalent. including contingencies): The aim of this component is to support those who have not been able to access education opportunities over recent years. This includes: (i) Youth aged 13-24 years who lack basic literacy, including those with young children who would benefit from ECD activities; (ii) Disadvantaged primary and secondary school-aged girls, and young women at the tertiary education level; and (iii) Under-served groups, including war widows and ex-combatants, who require basic skills development training for sustained livelihood and participation in society. 30. The component targets those who have not been able to access education using both the formal and non-formal systems of education to promote learning and skills acquisition. In particular, it recognizes the proven social and economic advantages of educating young mothers and preparing young children for future learning. This component comprises three sub- components: Literacy Learning and ECD (estimated cost US$1.1 million equivalent). This sub-component will address the literacy and basic education requirements of youth aged 13-24 years, with a particular focus on young women and adolescent girls, through non-formal classes for 7
 literacy acquisition. To provide young children with early learning opportunities, ECD activities will be linked to women's participation in NFE programs, and analyze the needs of young children, women, families and communities will be assessed in order to develop an ECD policy and a national program of NFE. Increasing the Number of Girls in School (estimated cost US$3.7 million equivalent). To promote girls' and young women's participation in the formal system of education at the primary, secondary and tertiary levels, a demand-side financing mechanism will encourage: (i) girls and young women to enroll in, and complete, a course of study at a secondary or tertiary-level institution of their choice through a capitation payment scheme; and (ii) children, especially girls of disadvantaged women, including war widows, to participate in primary or secondary schooling through a stipend scheme paid in cash or in-kind to their families. Skills Development for Underserved Groups (estimated cost US$1.0 million equivalent). To provide demand-driven skills development training to allow disadvantaged groups, including war widows and ex-combatants, opportunities for sustained livelihood and participation in society through the acquisition of new skills. It will support the training of instructors, rehabilitation of facilities, the provision of materials, textbooks, reference materials and training modules and learner stipends. Community centers offering technical and vocational training consisting of short-term courses in urgently required skills will be supported. 31. Component 2: Education Sector Management Reform (estimated cost US$5.7 million equivalent, including contingencies!: The aim of this component is to develop capacities to enable the effective design and management of the primary, secondary and tertiary education sub-sectors. Key partners in this are civil society, NGOs, and the private sector. This component includes two sub-components: Policy Development for the Education Sector (estimated cost US$1.0 million equivalent). This sub-component will develop a new sector policy framework, based on principles including, among others, social and gender equity, access and quality, as agreed during consultations between AIA and the multi-donor assessment mission of February 2002. The policy framework will include the definition of standards and qualifications of teachers, curriculum requirements, assessment of learning outcomes, and accreditation, as well as regulatory guidelines for the functioning of NGOs and private providers. This sub- component will support an institutional analysis and sector work to gain in-depth knowledge of the sector and development requirements. A baseline survey, providing information about basic human development indicators and allowing for measurement of the impact of policy and sector restructuring on outcomes, will also fall under this sub- component. Efforts will be made under the sub-component to provide greater access for women in policy and decision-making. In addition, the MOE will support the Government's work in carrying out a proposed Living Standard Measurement Survey (LSMS) which will provide the Government and other stakeholders with critical data and analysis to formulate policy in Afghanistan. Skills Development for Quality Schools and Institutions (estimated cost US$4.7 million equivalent). This sub-component will address the urgent skills capacity building 8
 requirements at all levels of the education system and provide the necessary material support for its functioning. Particular emphasis will be placed on strengthening public- private partnerships, the role of districts and communities, and the establishment of Village Education Committees (VECs) to support the on-going functioning and improvement of schools. The component will also address rehabilitation of the tertiary sub-sector starting with support to tertiary institutes and priority disciplines to address their most immediate needs to upgrade the quality of teaching and learning. 32. Component 3: Distance Learning and Communications (estimated cost US$3.5 million equivalent, including contingencies): The aim of this component is twofold: (i) to help strengthen the capacity of the Government of Afghanistan and the AACA through the use of information and communications technology to accelerate planning, implementation, and monitoring of the reconstruction process; and (ii) to provide a facility for distance learning which will support the management reform and capacity building processes of Component 2. This will foster knowledge transfer of global experience and good practice while allowing key personnel to stay on the job during this critical period of rebuilding. Establishment of a Distance Learning Center (DLC) (estimated cost US$1.7 million equivalent). The Project will support the establishment of the DLC within the AACA offices and linked to the University of Kabul, through provision of appropriate tools and programs to support the public sector skills capacity building for the future Afghan government. This will provide a delivery mechanism for capacity building to improve education management at the central, provincial and district levels of the MOE and MOHE, and for increased local level access to education management-related information and skills development, as per Component 2. Development of a Government Internet (estimated cost US$1.8 million equivalent). This sub- component will address communications requirements through the provision of a basic set of telecommunications, office and networking technology, including internet connectivity and supporting applications for a priority set of AIA Ministries. INSTITUTIONAL ARRANGEMENTS AND IMPLEMENTATION Institutional Arrangements 33. The Project will be implemented by three agencies: Ministry of Education (MOE), Ministry of Higher Education (MOHE) and the Afghanistan Assistance Coordination Authority (AACA), under the responsibility of the respective ministers and in close collaboration with NGOs, universities and provincial and local authorities and communities. Components 1 and 2 will be implemented by MOE and MOHE and Component 3 by the AACA. 34. Because these activities support a programmatic approach to the rehabilitation and development of the education system, overall coordination of the project will be with the Deputy Chairperson, AIA, with oversight responsibilities for the education portfolio. The Deputy Chairperson, AIA, who is currently the Minister of Women's Affairs, will establish a Steering Committee to include the Ministers of MOE and MOHE, and the Director of the AACA. This Steering Committee will be supported by a technical unit working closely with the three agencies. Day-to-day management and implementation of project activities will be the 9
 responsibilities of the respective line ministries and line directorates within those ministries. The line directorates will also ensure coordination of all other activities being carried out by other development partners, to ensure efficient use of resources. Project reporting will be done through the Steering Committee technical unit. The Steering Committee, as part of its coordination function, will hold quarterly meetings with all project stakeholders. Because the Project emphasizes capacity building, the MOE and MOHE in addition, will identify and appoint an adequate number of Government staff counterparts with requisite technical qualifications to implement the Project. Summary of Implementation Arrangements 35. Component 1: Promoting Skills Development and Learning: This component will be implemented through contracting arrangements with experienced lead NGOs who have, over the last several years, carried out literacy and ECD programs in Afghanistan, in close collaboration with local communities. Existing programs will be scaled up to expand literacy training coverage for youth aged 13-24 years. In addition, these lead NGOs will be contracted to provide technical assistance to smaller national NGOs, including the training of literacy instructors. NGOs implementing literacy programs for youth will also provide early childcare facilities, activities and appropriate instructional and play materials for the young children of the literacy learners. Technical support to be funded by the project to develop ECD literacy material for use in classes focusing on home-based early child development approaches. 36. To develop a policy framework for ECD, the project will provide technical, financial and material assistance to the NFE section of the MOE to organize and carry out workshops on international good practices in ECD. 37. A capitation system for eligible girls and women at the secondary and tertiary education levels will be introduced which will allow them to choose a secondary or tertiary institute for study. Capitation payments will be made to the institute at the completion of a girl's program of study, based on the establishment of baseline levels for girls' enrollment and paid according to incremental increases. A separate stipend scheme to assist children, especially girls, of disadvantaged women, including war widows, will be paid in cash or in-kind to families through a verification system to be established. 38. Technical and vocational training for disadvantaged groups will be carried out by competent NGOs with a proven track record in this area. It will be based on a analysis of demand for skills training and organized through linkages to industry and private business to foster employment and self-employment opportunities after training. 39. Contracting of NGOs for the expansion of literacy and technical and vocational programs will take place immediately after effectiveness. 40. Component 2: Education Sector Management Reform: In order to carry out this component, it will be essential that the MOE and MOHE identify a critical number of qualified civil servants who would be prepared to take on additional responsibilities, decision-making authority and be held accountable for meeting key performance targets. This can be understood as a 'Core Development Team' (CDT). Since CDT staff will be civil servants, salaries will not be financed from the Grant. 10
 41. It is anticipated that this core group of civil servants will require additional support in a number of key areas, such as policy development, planning, financial management, monitoring and evaluation, and various technical functions within the education sector. For the MOE and MOHE, it is recommended that this core group not exceed 20 persons per ministry. 42. For development of the policy framework and sector analyses, the project will provide technical assistance for the establishment of a Steering Committee chaired by the Deputy Chairperson responsible for the education portfolio and the Ministers from MOE and MOHE, with representation of major stakeholders from civil society including women's and parents' associations. Additional specialized technical assistance will be provided for selected units within the ministries, such as the Primary, Secondary, NFE, Technical/Vocational, Planning, Assessment/Accreditation, Curriculum and Teacher Training departments. The project will provide technical, financial and material support for a number of workshops and civil society consultations on policy to be held at the regional, provincial and community levels. The technical assistance contract is expected to be in place by September 2002. 43. For developing core skills in sectoral line directorates, technical assistance will be procured to design an on-the-job training program while supporting the day-to-day work of core staff at the central and provincial levels. Funds will also be available to procure short-term training through the DLC. 44. A small number of vehicles will be procured to provide mobility in provincial ministry offices, particularly to address the transport requirements of personnel in areas that are remote or difficult to reach. Computers, related IT support, and basic office equipment and supplies at the central and provincial levels will be funded from this sub-component through the procurement arrangements described in Appendix I. 45. For developing decentralized management structures, particularly at the community level, the project will support the establishment of VECs under the umbrella of the proposed CDD Project. A pilot scheme will be carried out during the first twelve months of the project targeting 100 villages. This will be designed and implemented through a contract with a qualified NGO with extensive experience in community participation in education. Following a successful pilot phase, this will be scaled-up to 500 villages during the second year of project implementation. 46. For improved district-level monitoring of schools for supporting quality teaching- learning, a lead NGO with a successful track record of providing quality inputs will be contracted. The procurement of basic office equipment and supplies for district level ministry offices will be funded from this sub-component through the procurement arrangements described in Appendix I, with priority given to those districts which are being supported by an NGO for improved monitoring of schools. 47. Sub-Grants, i.e., block grants, for a maximum amount of US$100,000 each will be awarded to tertiary-level institutes addressing the most immediate needs of institutes and priority disciplines. Grants to institutes will be awarded by a management committee following approval by the President and two faculty deans. A Management Committee will make site visits to validate proposals prior to the release of funds, and seek agreements on milestones for which 11
 disbursements will take place. All proposals from institutes will be submitted collectively in order to streamline procurement of goods and services. 48. Expenditure categories to be financed by block grants are: (a) technical assistance; (b) books; (c) computers; (d) laboratory equipment; (e) short-term training in Afghanistan and South Asia; (f) civil works; (g) vehicles; and (h) furniture. Excluded for funding are: (a) long-term fellowships abroad; (b) construction of new buildings; and (c) establishment of new institutions. The block grants will be implemented in line with the agreed criteria shown in Appendix IV. 49. The Environmental and Social Safeguards Framework provides general policies, guidelines, codes of practice and procedures to be integrated into the implementation of IDA- supported emergency reconstruction operations in Afghanistan. Consistent with existing national legislation, the objective of the Framework is to help ensure that activities under the proposed reconstruction operations will: * Protect human health; * Prevent or compensate any loss of livelihood; * Prevent environmental degradation as a result of either individual sub-projects or their cumulative effects; * Enhance positive environmental and social outcomes; and, * Ensure compliance with IDA safeguard policies. General Principles 2. Recognizing the emergency nature of the proposed relief and reconstruction operations, and the related need for providing immediate assistance, while at the same time ensuring due diligence in managing potential environmental and social risks, this Framework is based on the following principles: The proposed operations will support multiple sub-projects, the detailed designs of which may not be known at appraisal. To ensure the effective application of IDA's safeguard policies, the Framework provides guidance on the approach to be taken during implementation for the selection and design of sub-projects, and the planning of mitigation measures; * The proposed emergency reconstruction operations will not support environmental Category A sub-projects, nor sub-projects requiring land acquisition affecting 200 or more people. Consequently, no Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) or Resettlement Action Plans (RAPs) will be required. With the exception of support for the emergency rehabilitation of the Kabul North-West power plant, no sub-projects requiring separate, site-specific environmental or social reports will be supported. With this exception, all proposed sub-projects will be screened to ensure that the environmental and social risks can be adequately addressed through the application of standardized guidelines and codes of practice; * Activities requiring a more detailed level of assessment, such as those entailing the construction or installation of new or significantly expanded infrastructure, will be supported under subsequent operations. The proposed emergency reconstruction operations will finance feasibility and detailed design studies for these subsequent investments, which will include environmental and social impact assessments as required by IDA safeguard policies; 6As defined in World Bank Operational Policy 4.01, Environmental Assessment. 59
 Project design and sub-project selection will aim to maintain regional balance, and equity between genders, and ethnic and religious groups, considering variations in population density. Employment opportunities within the projects will be available on an equal basis to all, on the basis of professional competence, irrespective of gender, or ethnic or religious group. In all projects which require consultations with local communities or beneficiaries, gender-separated consultations will be conducted to elicit the views of the female population, along with that of the male population; and, Consultation and disclosure requirements will be simplified to meet the special needs of these operations. Prior to approval by World Bank Board, this Environmental and Social Safeguards Framework will be disclosed in Afghanistan in Dari and Pashto, and in the World Bank Infoshop. Safeguard Screening and Mitigation 3. The selection, design, contracting, monitoring and evaluation of sub-projects will be consistent with the following guidelines, codes of practice and requirements: * A negative list of characteristics that would make a proposed sub-project ineligible for support, as indicated in Attachment 1; * Guidelines for land and asset acquisition, entitlements and compensation, presented in Attachment 2; * Procedures for the protection of cultural property, including the chance discovery of archaeological artifacts, and unrecorded graveyards and burial sites, provided in Attachment 3; * Relevant elements of the codes of practice for the mitigation of potential environmental impacts, presented in Attachment 4; and, • The requirement that confirmation is received through the Regional Mine Action Center that areas to be accessed during reconstruction and rehabilitation activities have been demined. 4. In addition to these requirements, an environmental audit will be conducted as part of feasibility study and detailed design for the rehabilitation of the Kabul North-West power plant. Responsibilities for Safeguard Screening and Mitigation 5. A number of Ministries will act as the implementing agencies for the proposed operations, including the Ministries of Reconstruction and Rural Development, Public Works, Power, and Housing, Planning and Building. Each Ministry will be responsible for applying the safeguard screening and mitigation requirements to its own sub-projects. 6. Within each Ministry, a Safeguards Focal Point will be identified with responsibility for overseeing the implementation of the Environmental and Social Safeguards Framework. 60
 Capacity Building and Monitoring of Safeguard Framework Implementation 7. As part of the capacity building that will be provided for implementation of the proposed operations, the Safeguards Focal Points and relevant staff of the concerned Ministries will also receive training in the application of the Safeguard Framework. 8. To assist in this capacity building, and to provide subsequent guidance and review of the application of the Framework, GoA will contract specialist social and environmental services. During supervision of these operations, IDA will assess the implementation of the Framework, and if required will recommend additional strengthening. Consultation and Disclosure 9. This Environmental and Social Safeguards Framework was prepared in consultation with the principal NGOs and development partners participating in reconstruction activities in Afghanistan. It will be disclosed by GoA in both Dari and Pashto, as well as English, and it will also be made available at the World Bank's Infoshop. 10. The environmental audit to be prepared for the rehabilitation of the Kabul North-West thermal power station will be made publicly available by GoA, and at the World Bank Infoshop. Since no other separate environmental or social assessments will be prepared for activities under the proposed reconstruction operations, no additional disclosure requirements will apply. In this regard, however, it is worth noting that GoA intends to make all project documentation publicly available through the Afghan Information Management System (AIMS). 11. The proposed operations will support a number of feasibility and detailed design studies for future infrastructure investments, for which IDA safeguard policies relating to consultation and disclosure will apply. In particular, for environmental Category A and B investments7 proposed for future operations, the implementing agency will consult project-affected groups and local nongovernmental organizations about the project's environmental and social aspects, and will take their views into account. The implementing agency will initiate such consultations as early as possible, and for meaningful consultations, will provide relevant material in a timely manner prior to consultation, in a form and language that are understandable and accessible to the groups being consulted. 12. For Category A projects, the implementing agency will consult these groups at least twice, (i) shortly after environmental screening and before the terms of reference for the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) are finalized, and (ii) once a draft EIA report is prepared. For the initial consultation, the implementing agency will provide a summary of the proposed project's objectives, description, and potential impacts. For both Category A and B projects, the implementing agency will provide these groups with a summary of the EIA report's conclusions. In addition, the implementing agency will make the draft reports available at a public place accessible to project-affected groups and local NGOs. 7As defined in World Bank Operational Policy 4.01, Environmental Assessment. 61

 APPENDIX VI Attachment 2 Guidelines for Land and Asset Acquisition, Entitlements and Compensation Objectives 1. Land acquisition will be kept to a minimum and no person will be involuntarily displaced under sub-projects financed by the proposed emergency reconstruction operations. Sub-project proposals that would require demolishing houses or acquiring productive land should be carefully reviewed to minimize or avoid their impacts through alternative alignments. Proposals that require more than minor expansion along rights of way should be reviewed carefully. No land or asset acquisition may take place outside of these guidelines. A format for Land Acquisition Assessment is attached as Annex 1. 2. These guidelines provide principles and instructions to compensate affected persons to ensure that all such persons negatively affected, regardless of their land tenure status, will be assisted to improve, or at least to restore, their living standards, income earning or production capacity to pre-project levels. Categorization 3. Based on the number of persons that may be affected by the project (Project Affected People, PAPs) and the magnitude of impacts, projects may be categorized as S-1, S-2, or S-3 projects: a. S-I projects are those that will involve the resettlement of more than 200 PAPs and where a full Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) must be produced. Such interventions will be ineligible for support under the proposed emergency reconstruction operations. b. S-2 projects are those which will involve the resettlement of less than 200 persons. In such cases, the following documentation is required: (1) a land acquisition assessment, (2) the Minutes or record of consultations which assess the compensation claimed and agreement reached, and (3) a record of the receipt of the compensation, or voluntary donation, by those affected (see below). c. S-3 projects are not expected to have any land acquisition or any other significant adverse social impacts; on the contrary, significant positive social impact and improved livelihoods are expected from such interventions. Eligibility 4. PAPs are identified as persons whose livelihood is directly or indirectly affected by the project. PAPs deemed eligible for compensation are: a. those who have formal legal rights to land, water resources or structures/buildings, including recognized customary and traditional rights; b. those who do not have such formal legal rights but have a claim to usufruct right rooted in customary law; and 64
 c. those whose claim to land and water resources or building/structures do not fall within (1) and (2) above, are eligible to assistance to restore their livelihood. Acquisition of Productive Assets and Compensation 5. PAPs are eligible for replacement costs for lost assets as described below: a. Voluntary contributions. In accordance with traditional practices, individuals may elect to voluntarily contribute land or assets and/or relocate temporarily or permanently from their land without compensation. b. Contributions against compensation. A contributor/asset loser considered "affected" will be eligible for compensation from the local community or alternatively from the Government. A PAP shall lodge his/her claim for compensation to the local community representatives/shura head and it shall be verified by the implementing agency. The claim shall be lodged within 2 weeks of completion of the consultations with the concerned community, and before project implementation begins. 6. Voluntary contribution, or contribution against compensation, should be documented. The documentation should specify that the land is free of any squatters, encroachers or other claims. A format is attached in Annex 2, which includes a Schedule to be followed to assess any compensation claimed and the agreement reached. Compensation Principles 7. The project implementing agencies shall ensure that any of the following means of compensation are provided in a timely manner to affected persons: Project affected persons losing access to a portion of their land or other productive assets with the remaining assets being economically viable are entitled to compensation at replacement cost for that portion of land or assets lost to them. Compensation for the lost assets will be according to following principles: a. replacement land with an equally productive plot, cash or other equivalent productive assets; b. materials and assistance to fully replace solid structures that will be demolished; c. replacement of damaged or lost crops and trees, at market value; d. other acceptable in-kind compensation; e. in case of cash compensation, the delivery of compensation should be made in public, i.e. at the Community Meeting. Project affected persons losing access to a portion of their land or other economic assets rendering the remainder economically non-viable, will have the options of compensation for the entire asset by provision of alternative land, cash or equivalent productive asset, according to the principles in (1) a-d above. 65
 Consultation Process 8. The implementing agencies will ensure that all occupants of land and owners of assets located in a proposed sub-project area are consulted. There will be gender-separate community meetings for each affected mantaqa/gozar (urban infrastructure) or village (other projects) to inform the local population about their rights to compensation and options available in accordance with these Guidelines. The Minutes of the community meetings shall reflect the discussions held, agreements reached, and include details of the agreement, based on the format provided in Annex 2. 9. The implementing agency shall provide a copy of the Minutes to affected persons and confirm in discussions with each of them their requests and preferences for compensation, agreements reached, and any eventual complaint. Copies will be recorded in the posted project documentation and be available for inspection during supervision. Sub-project Approval 10. In the event that a sub-project involves acquisition against compensation, the implementing agency shall: a. not approve the sub-project unless a satisfactory compensation has been agreed between the affected person and the local community; b. not allow works to start until the compensation has been delivered in a satisfactory manner to the affected persons; c. if more than 200 persons are affected and require compensation, the sub-project shall be deemed ineligible for support under the emergency reconstruction operations. Complaints and Grievances 11. All complaints should first be negotiated to reach an agreement at the local community/village level. If this falls, complaints and grievances about these Guidelines, implementation of the agreements recorded in the Community Meeting Minutes or any alleged irregularity in carrying out the project can also be addressed by the affected persons or their representative at the municipal or district level. If this also fails, the complaint may be submitted to the relevant implementing agency for a decision. Verification 12. The Community Meeting Minutes, including agreements of compensation and evidence of compensation having been made shall be provided to the Municipality/district, to the supervising engineers, who will maintain a record hereof, and to auditors and socio-economic monitors when they undertake reviews and post-project assessment. This process shall be specified in all relevant project documents, including details of the relevant authority for complaints at municipal/district or implementing agency level. 66

Physical culture includes monuments, structures, works of art, or sites of "outstanding universal value" from the historical, aesthetic, scientific, ethnological, or anthropological point of view, including unrecorded graveyards and burial sites. Within this broader definition, cultural property is defined as sites and structures having archaeological, paleontological, historical, architectural, or religious significance, and natural sites with cultural values. 2. The proposed emergency reconstruction operations are unlikely to pose a risk of damaging cultural property, as the sub-projects will largely consist of small investments in community infrastructure and income generating activities, reconstruction of existing structures, and minor urban public works. Further, the negative list of attributes, which would make a sub- project ineligible for support (Attachment 1), includes any activity that would significantly damage non-replicable cultural property. Nevertheless, the following procedures for identification, protection from theft, and treatment of chance finds should be followed and included in standard bid documents. Chance Find Procedures 3. Chance find procedures are defined in the law on Maintenance of Historical and Cultural Monuments (Official Gazette, December 21, 1980), specifying the authorities and responsibilities of cultural heritage agencies if sites or materials are discovered in the course of project implementation. This law establishes that all moveable and immovable historical and cultural artifacts are state property, and further: a. The responsibility for preservation, maintenance and assessment of historical and cultural monuments rests with the Archaeological Committee under the Ministry of Information and Culture, which has representation at provincial level. b. Whenever chance finds of cultural or historical artifacts (moveable and immovable) are made the Archaeological Committee should be informed. Should the continuation of work endanger the historical and cultural artifacts, the project work should be suspended until a solution is found for the preservation of these artifacts. c. If a moveable or immovable historical or cultural artifact is found in the countryside of a province, the provincial governor (wali) or district-in-charge (woluswal) should be informed within two weeks, and they should inforrn the Archaeological Committee. In case the immovable historical or cultural artifact is found in a city, the provincial branch of the Department of Maintenance of Historical Values of the Ministry of Information and Culture should be informed within two weeks (art. 18). If the find is made within the center, the Archaeological Committee must be informed. directly within one week (art. 25). d. Failure to report a chance find within the stipulated time limit will be punished with a fine or imprisonment for a period of one week or up to one month (art. 72). 70

These procedures must be referred to as standard provisions in construction contracts, when applicable. During project supervision, the Site Engineer shall monitor that the above regulations relating to the treatment of any chance find encountered are observed. 6. doc.repnme: Afghanistan - Emergency Education Rehabilitation and Development Project
doc.abstracts: The project overall objective is to selectively support the Government's emergency education program, by specifically helping in increasing access to education in both the formal, and non-formal education systems for under-served groups, in particular women and girls, Moreover, the project will prod education management reforms at all levels, in partnership with civil society, nongovernmental organizations, and the private sector, in addition to introducing modern information technologies for communications, and distance learning. However, there are significant risk categories for this project, namely, the potential deterioration within the political and security context, the limited implementation capacity, the non-payment issue of teachers' salaries, in addition to the likely inability to disburse (or misuse) project funds. It is foreseen that the benefits of the project, and its appropriate design, should mitigate those risks.
